results.title: Highfire: plan for survival
results.creator_credit: William Brose Productions, William Brose and Bruce Kerner
results.brief_description: Fire in high-rise buildings is a possibility that cannot be overlooked. This film is designed for all levels of employees and management in multi-storey buildings, and is a motivational film, demanding the viewer’s response to their own fire safety program.
results.creator_credit_for_label: William Brose Productions, William Brose and Bruce Kerner

results.title: Higher than high
results.creator_credit: Australian Film Commission, Film Victoria, Liz Meyers and Virginia Murray
results.brief_description: 2000 years after Icarus and 200 years since the first flight of an air balloon, a young man finds himself afloat in the atmosphere, sitting in an ordinary garden chair and boyed by a collection of weather balloons. This humurous and endearing Australian short recounts the true story of a man, living somewhere west of Shepparton, who after sinking a few drinks and smoking a few joints at a party, finds himself a passenger in a makeshift aircraft. Bizarre and entertaining, “Higher than High” also portrays the unique sounds and textures of Australian rural life.

results.title: High voltage
results.creator_credit: Shan Benson, Australian National Film Board and SEC
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “SEC Documentary films from the period 1950-1993”.
Building Victoria’s 500KV system: recounts the building of Victoria’s 500KV line for power transfer from the Yallourn Power Station to Melbourne. Shows planning and testing of towers, film of actual construction of line land clearing and excavation of sites for towers. The film describes some of the planning and construction of the 500KV line - designed to carry power from the future generating stations of the Latrobe Valley to the local centre in Melbourne. Shows rolling out and cutting of the power cabling, installation of equipment at Hazelwood Plant, preparation and countdown for energizing in June, 1970. Photography by Jim Hayes. “Along the power lines” (1962): dramatised account of the work of the mobile repair units of the SEC. Shows film of the irrigation reservoir at Eildon and pipelines at Kiewa, power lines crossing the Murray River Valley joining New South Wales with Victoria and the various parts involved in the process of electricity production from brown coal. Footage of the power plants and lines shows inside the control centre near Melbourne, with the technicians at work monitoring the load on supply. Photography by John Leake with aerial photography by Jim Hayes.

results.title: High temperature research
results.creator_credit: Arthur Campbell, David W. Ridgway and Centron Production
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Chemical Education Material Study Series”.
The procedures for producing and measuring temperatures in the region of 2000 degrees are shown. Also studies the bond strength of gaseous titanium monosulphide and shows how its gaseous molecules as well as gaseous titanium and sulphur atoms are produced by the vaporisation of the high melting crystalline titanium monosulphide at this temperature.

results.title: High steel
results.creator_credit: Julian Biggs, ONF | NFB and Don Owen
results.brief_description: This film from the National Film Board of Canada profiles a Mohawk Indian from Kahnawake just outside of Montreal Canada, who is a steelworker, working on the construction of skyscrapers in Manhatten New York. The Mohawk Indians from Kahnawake are famous for erecting the steel frames of skyscrapers and it is a tradition, which goes back generations. Some truly death-defining footage is shown of the steelworkers up on top of buildings skillfully shifting metal beams into position. The Indians community life is also shown in Kahnawake as well as some stunning historical photographs of Indians working on the Quebec Bridge in 1907 which ended in disaster. A song ballad by Bruce Mackay called Mountains of Iron and Steel is effectively mixed through the film. Directed by Don Owen.

results.title: High stakes. Ep. 3. Gambling fever [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: BBC, TLC Films and Sarah Hann
results.brief_description: This is a three-part program on all aspects of gambling, both legal and illegal and how gambling has transformed in the last 50 years from an activity that society regarded as illegal and immoral into something that is respectable, accessible and very big business. Modern gambling relies on the gambler’s willingness to take a chance. Ep. 3. Gambling fever: During the 1990s casinos in Las Vegas became huge entertainment and leisure centres catering not only to gamblers but also to the needs of families. Casinos full of slot machines and video poker began to spread throughout America causing grief and addiction to many families and division within the native Americans as they battled over the establishment of casinos on their reservations. In the UK the restrictive laws in gambling began to ease and that country too began to experience an increase in gambling addiction right across the board, particularly in the sporting area where horse races, soccer matches and even international cricket matches were open to corruption and “fixing”. Australia is also examined in this episode as an emerging gambling superpower susceptible to corruption and organized crime. The introduction of national lotteries and instant access to internet gambling enabled all socio-economic levels in society to participate in this already saturated industry. In this program, the interviews focus more on the down side of gambling, the desperation of the addicted and the tragic consequences which can result including criminal activities, jail, drugs or even death. Also includes interviews from the anti-gambling bodies who are overwhelmed by the fall-out and lack of support for problem gamblers. This is quite an amazing series containing honest and often confronting interviews with some of those who have experienced gambling in all its forms or who have been involved in the industry, legally or illegally. Uses archival footage and includes some b&w scenes. Presented by John Inverdale. For more informations see “www.bbc.co.uk/highstakes”

results.title: High stakes. Ep. 2. Easy money [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: BBC, TLC Films and Jeremy Monblat
results.brief_description: This is a three-part program on all aspects of gambling, both legal and illegal and how gambling has transformed in the last 50 years from an activity that society regarded as illegal and immoral into something that is respectable, accessible and very big business. Modern gambling relies on the gambler’s willingness to take a chance. Ep. 2. Easy money: During the 1960s and 1970s casinos thrived in London, and none more so than the famous Playboy Club (1965-81) with its “bunny” girls. The many casinos attracted a second wave of high rollers from the oil rich Middle East and eventually a casino war broke out between Playboy and Ladbrokes over the custom of these wealthy Arab high rollers. Dirty tricks were played by both sides ending in both clubs losing their licenses. Meanwhile in Las Vegas (1966), the eccentric Howard Hughes through first purchasing the Desert Inn Hotel and then several other major hotels including The Sands and The Silver Slipper, opens the door for corporations to own and invest in the gambling city finally bringing an end to mafia control. By the early 1970s slot machines (pokies) took over from the table games in revenue and it is these very slot machines which built today’s Vegas. The mafia’s final death throe in Vegas is presented from all points of view - members of the Mob, the casino managers and the law-enforcers and includes scenes from the film “Casino” starring Robert De Niro, which dramatises the real-life story of the Chicago Mob’s inevitable downfall. Enter Wall Street and the world of corporations - and enter too the 80s and 90s and the world of slot machines - easy money! Features personal narratives and commentary from a wide array of gamblers, ex-gamblers, and those who work or are involved in the industry. Also contains archival footage with some scenes in b&w. Presented by John Inverdale. For more information see “www.bbc.co.uk/highstakes”

results.title: High stakes. Ep. 1. Dangerous games [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Peter Molloy, BBC and TLC Films
results.brief_description: This is a three-part program on all aspects of gambling, both legal and illegal and how gambling has transformed in the last 50 years from an activity that society regarded as illegal and immoral into something that is respectable, accessible and very big business. Modern gambling relies on the gambler’s willingness to take a chance. Ep. 1. Dangerous games: Excitement, money, greed, living on the edge, addictive, power and control are just some of the words used by the interviewees in this program. Gambling it seems has no limit to a person’s behaviour and just how far they are willing to go - some even to the point of death. Mark “Chopper” Read talks of his “rush” when he plays Russian Roulette, others get their excitement from betting on “dares” and playing weird games for money. There are so many ways to gamble - at the casinos, on the horses, playing the pokies and since gambling was legalised in Nevada in 1931, availability and those who are playing at the casinos has increased dramatically. This episode provides a historical background of gambling in America and the UK, focusing on the 1960s, the mafia involvement both in Las Vegas and London, and the change in attitude by society towards the “gambler”, particularly the “high rollers”. Features personal narratives and commentary from a wide array of gamblers, ex-gamblers, and those who work or are involved in the industry, including members of the Mob and associates of the Kray brothers. Fascinating up-front viewing, with tales of violence, murder, corruption, manipulation, fixing, winners, losers, and the whole “sexy” glam lifestyle associated with gambling. Contains archival footage including some b&w scenes. Presented by John Inverdale. For more information see “www.bbc.co.uk/highstakes” WARNING: Contains strong language.

Mark “Chopper” Read talks of his “rush” when he plays Russian Roulette, others get their excitement from betting on “dares” and playing weird games for money. There are so many ways to gamble - at the casinos, on the horses, playing the pokies and since gambling was legalised in Nevada in 1931, availability and those who are playing at the casinos has increased dramatically. This episode provides a historical background of gambling in America and the UK, focusing on the 1960s, the mafia involvement both in Las Vegas and London, and the change in attitude by society towards the “gambler”, particularly the “high rollers”. Features personal narratives and commentary from a wide array of gamblers, ex-gamblers, and those who work or are involved in the industry, including members of the Mob and associates of the Kray brothers. Fascinating up-front viewing, with tales of violence, murder, corruption, manipulation, fixing, winners, losers, and the whole “sexy” glam lifestyle associated with gambling. Contains archival footage including some b&w scenes. Presented by John Inverdale. For more information see “www.bbc.co.uk/highstakes” WARNING: Contains strong language.
description_for_label: This is a three-part program on all aspects of gambling, both legal and illegal and how gambling has transformed in the last 50 years from an activity that society regarded as illegal and immoral into something that is respectable, accessible and very big business. Modern gambling relies on the gambler’s willingness to take a chance. Ep. 1. Dangerous games: Excitement, money, greed, living on the edge, addictive, power and control are just some of the words used by the interviewees in this program. Gambling it seems has no limit to a person’s behaviour and just how far they are willing to go - some even to the point of death. Mark “Chopper” Read talks of his “rush” when he plays Russian Roulette, others get their excitement from betting on “dares” and playing weird games for money. There are so many ways to gamble - at the casinos, on the horses, playing the pokies and since gambling was legalised in Nevada in 1931, availability and those who are playing at the casinos has increased dramatically. This episode provides a historical background of gambling in America and the UK, focusing on the 1960s, the mafia involvement both in Las Vegas and London, and the change in attitude by society towards the “gambler”, particularly the “high rollers”. Features personal narratives and commentary from a wide array of gamblers, ex-gamblers, and those who work or are involved in the industry, including members of the Mob and associates of the Kray brothers. Fascinating up-front viewing, with tales of violence, murder, corruption, manipulation, fixing, winners, losers, and the whole “sexy” glam lifestyle associated with gambling. Contains archival footage including some b&w scenes. Presented by John Inverdale. For more information see “www.bbc.co.uk/highstakes” WARNING: Contains strong language.

results.title: High society (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Sol Siegel, Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, United Artists Corporation and Charles Walters
results.brief_description: Bing Crosby, Grace Kelly and Frank Sinatra romp elegantly through the scenic, moneyed grounds and waters of outwardly elitist Newport, Rhode Island in this hip, witty, musical version of Philip Barry’s ‘The Philadelphia story’. Legendary Louis Armstrong, starring as himself, plays his trumpet and narrates in prose and song the peccadillos of his song-writer friend C. K. Dexter-Haven as he tries to win back his haughty ex-wife on the eve of her marriage. Music by Cole Porter.
